text: Welcome Yixin. Let's start — tell me about yourself and your product management experience.

Thanks for having me. So I've been a PM for about 4 years. Most recently at a B2B SaaS company, analytics platform. We grew from like 500 to 5000 DAU. I led a team of 8 engineers. Yeah, it was a good experience.
Good. Can you tell me specifically what you did to drive that growth from 500 to 5000 users?

Um, so we did a lot of things. We improved the onboarding flow, added some key integrations that users were asking for, and also did some marketing campaigns. I think the biggest thing was probably the integrations — like Slack and Salesforce — because enterprise customers really needed those.
What was your specific role in that? How did you decide which integrations to prioritize?

Right, so I used a framework. I categorize features into must-haves, performance features, and delighters using the Kano model. Then I score each on impact versus effort. For integrations specifically, Slack was the clear winner because 80% of our enterprise pipeline mentioned it in sales calls.
OK. Let me shift to a scenario question. You're a PM at a social media company. Your weekly active users dropped 15% over the past month. Walk me through how you'd investigate.

OK so... 15% drop. That's significant. Um, first I'd want to check if it's across all users or just specific segments. Like, is it new users or existing users? And also maybe look at geographic data to see if it's a regional thing.
Let's say the data shows it's primarily in existing users, and it's global — not regional.

Hmm OK. So if it's existing users globally... I'd probably look at recent product changes. Like did we ship anything in the last month that could have affected the experience? Maybe a redesign or removing a feature. I'd also check, um, competitors — did anyone launch something that's pulling users away?
Good direction. But how would you actually structure this investigation? What's your systematic approach?

Yeah, I guess I'd look at a few things. Session frequency, time spent per session, which features they're using less. And then try to correlate that with any product changes or external events. Like maybe there's a changelog I can cross-reference with the drop timeline.
What metric would you prioritize looking at first, and why?

Hmm, probably session frequency? Because if people are coming back less often, that tells me it's an engagement issue rather than like a loading speed or crash problem. But actually, maybe I should look at retention curves first — like day-7 and day-30 retention — to see if it's a sudden cliff or gradual decline.
You changed your answer there. That's fine. Let's move on. Tell me about a time you had a significant disagreement with your engineering team about priorities.

Oh yeah, that happens a lot. So there was this time when engineering wanted to spend a whole sprint on refactoring the backend, and I had this important feature that sales was pushing for. It was tough because I understood the tech debt argument but the sales team was saying we'd lose deals.
How did you resolve it?

I believe in data-driven discussions. I bring user research data, usage metrics, and competitive analysis to the table. If engineering has technical concerns about implementation complexity, I work with them to find a phased approach. Sometimes the best solution is a simpler MVP that validates the assumption first.
That sounds quite general. What specifically happened in that situation you mentioned? What was the outcome?

Right, sorry. So in that specific case, we ended up splitting the sprint — two weeks for the feature and one week for the most critical refactoring. The feature shipped on time and sales closed three deals with it. The refactoring... honestly we didn't get to finish it until two sprints later, which the engineers weren't super happy about.
Interesting. Looking back, would you do anything differently?

Hmm, I think I would have communicated the timeline for the refactoring better upfront. Like, made it an explicit commitment rather than just saying 'we'll get to it.' The engineers felt like their priorities kept getting deprioritized, and that damaged trust a bit.
Have you ever had to influence a senior stakeholder — like a VP or C-level — to change direction on something?

Um, not directly a C-level. But I've worked with our VP of Sales on roadmap priorities. He wanted us to build custom features for a single large client, and I pushed back by showing that the feature wouldn't benefit our broader user base. I showed the usage data and... yeah, he eventually agreed to a more generalizable solution.
How did you structure that conversation? What data did you use to convince him?

I showed him that the custom feature would only serve that one client, but if we built it as a configurable module, it could serve maybe 30% of our enterprise segment. I also estimated the engineering cost difference — it was only like 20% more effort for 10x the reach. So the ROI argument was pretty clear.
Last question — do you have any questions for me about the role or the team?
Yeah, just one — how is the PM team structured here? Like, how much autonomy do PMs have?
